Icd 9 Diabetic Ketoacidosis

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes that occurs when the body produces high levels of blood acids called ketones. It is most commonly seen in individuals with type 1 diabetes, but can also occur in those with type 2 diabetes.

The International Classification of Diseases, 9th Revision (ICD-9) is a coding system used by healthcare professionals to classify and code diagnoses and procedures. The ICD-9 code for diabetic ketoacidosis is 250.1.

DKA occurs when there is a lack of insulin in the body, leading to a buildup of glucose in the blood. This causes the body to break down fat for energy, resulting in the production of ketones. High levels of ketones can lead to a dangerous condition called ketoacidosis.

Symptoms of DKA include excessive thirst, frequent urination, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, and confusion. If left untreated, DKA can lead to coma or even death.

Treatment for DKA involves restoring fluids and electrolytes, correcting blood sugar levels, and administering insulin. Hospitalization is often required to closely monitor the patient's condition and provide necessary medical interventions.

Prevention of DKA involves proper management of diabetes, including regular monitoring of blood sugar levels, taking prescribed medications as directed, and following a healthy diet and exercise regimen.

In conclusion, diabetic ketoacidosis is a serious complication of diabetes that requires prompt medical attention. The ICD-9 code for DKA is 250.1, which is used by healthcare professionals to classify and code this condition. Proper management of diabetes is crucial in preventing DKA and its potentially life-threatening consequences.
